study_plan_entry.title: Determination of the Structure of a single Crystal from Diffraction Data

free_text.Note: Regarding the exam: Each candidate shall solve a not too difficult structure before the eyes of one of the instructors within 4 hours and shall be examined accordingly.
free_text.Required prior knowledge: Mainly basic linear algebra, analysis and electromagnetism
free_text.Content: The concept of symmetry as isometries in the Euclidean Space E3, then point groups and space groups in E3 (incommensurate structures and quasicrystal shall be disregarded). Production of X-rays and associated safety. [br/]The kinematic theory of the diffraction of X-rays by a 3p pattern of atoms or molecules. Symmetry in reciprocal space and the phase problem, systematic absences and 2nd order displacement parameters. [br/]Direct methods for phasing intensities (probabilistic) and the charge-flipping-method. [br/]Patterson's method. Diffractometers (image plates and CCD versions) and data reduction. Refinements, interpretation of the resolts and preparation of high-quality CIF-files. [br/]Detailed presentation of the SHELX-program. Hands-on experience for crystal-mounting, strategy for data collection, data reduction and determination of two structures. [br/]Particular attention shall be paid to exercises illustrating the concepts presented in the lectures.[br/][br/]
free_text.Learning outcomes: To provide the participants the necessary theoritical and practical knowledge for independently determinating a crystal structure from single crystal or powder data. [br/]In particular, symmetry theory, diffraction theory, direct methods (including charge flipping), the heavy atom-method, refinement and data treatment shall be taught at a moderately advanced level, [br/]but without requiring prior knowledge. Some importance shall be given to proficiency in using the International Tables for Crystallography, the pertinent data bases, the crystallographic literature and preparing CIF-files.
